entry.title: Building an SAP-RPT-1 "Hello World" with AI Core
entry.content:
Using SAP-RPT-1 in the playground is a nice way to get a first impression, but you'll soon realize there are some limitations. In this blog post, let's explore how to use SAP-RPT-1 in a production-like environment. I'll walk you through the steps to build a simple "Hello World" application using SAP-RPT-1 and AI Core.

 
 

Creating a Deployment for SAP-RPT-1

Throughout this blog post, I'll assume that you have access to a BTP subaccount with instances of the AI Core service (extended plan) and the AI Launchpad service (standard plan).

First, you need to create a configuration for SAP-RPT-1 with the following parameters:

  • Configuration Name: For example, sap-rpt-1-large or sap-rpt-1-small (I recommend naming the configuration so that you can easily recognize the underlying model)
  • Scenario: foundation-models
  • Version: 0.0.1 (default value)
  • Executable: aicore-sap (meaning that this model is hosted by SAP; you can find this value in note 3437766)
  • Model Name: sap-rpt-1-large or sap-rpt-1-small (again, as per note 3437766)
  • Model Version: latest

In the next step, you can turn this configuration into a deployment by clicking on the "Create Deployment" button in the configuration overview. You can leave all the default values as they are and create the deployment.

After a few minutes, the deployment should reach the status "Running" and you can start using it. Note that a deployment URL has also been created, something like https://api.ai.prod.eu-central-1.aws.ml.hana.ondemand.com/v2/inference/deployments/1234567890abcdef. The most important part is the deployment ID at the end of the URL (in this example 1234567890abcdef), which you'll need later on.

 
 

Handling AI Core Authentication

At the time of writing, the SAP Cloud SDK for Python does not yet support the RPT-1 models. Following the documentation, we will therefore use the requests library to call the deployment endpoint directly.

Before we can do that, however, we need to authenticate as also described in the documentation. What may look intimidating at first is actually quite straightforward. We only need a few parameters which we'll store securely in a .env file. You can collect this information from the service key of your AI Core instance.

AICORE_API_URL="https://api.ai.prod.eu-central-1.aws.ml.hana.ondemand.com/v2"
AICORE_AUTH_URL="https://a1b2c3d4e4f61234.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com" # called "url" in the service key
AICORE_CLIENT_ID="sb-95d9f03d" # shortened, yours will be longer
AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET="c51ad55c"  # shortened, yours will be longer
AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP="default"  # your actual resource group

Additionally, store the RPT deployment ID(s) you collected earlier:

RPT1L_DEPLOYMENT_ID="1234567890abcdef"  # your actual deployment ID for RPT-1 large
RPT1S_DEPLOYMENT_ID="abcdef1234567890"  # your actual deployment ID for RPT-1 small

Once the .env file is ready, we can use the following code to retrieve an access token from the authentication endpoint:

 
#!pip install python-dotenv # install if not already installed
 
import os
import requests
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load .env file
load_dotenv()

AICORE_AUTH_URL = os.environ["AICORE_AUTH_URL"]
AICORE_CLIENT_ID = os.environ["AICORE_CLIENT_ID"]
AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET = os.environ["AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET"]

token_url = f"{AICORE_AUTH_URL}/oauth/token"

response = requests.post(
    token_url,
    auth=(AICORE_CLIENT_ID, AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET),
    data={"grant_type": "client_credentials"},
)

response.raise_for_status()

token_data = response.json()
access_token = token_data["access_token"]
 
 

Preparing Test Data

For testing the connection to the RPT-1 deployment, we'll use the same test data we used when trying out RPT-1 in the playground. Here's the test data in the format RPT-1 expects:

Note: For the next steps, I also created a Jupyter notebook, which you can download to interactively do all the steps below yourself.

 
payload = {
    "prediction_config": {
        "target_columns": [
            {
                "name": "SALESGROUP",
                "prediction_placeholder": "[PREDICT]"
                # "task_type": "classification" or "regression" can be specified here if needed
            }
        ]
    },
    "index_column": "ID",
    "rows": [
        {
            "ID": "1001",
            "PRODUCT": "Tablet",
            "PRICE": 599.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "TechStart Inc",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1002",
            "PRODUCT": "Standing Desk",
            "PRICE": 325.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "Workspace Solutions",
            "COUNTRY": "Germany",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1003",
            "PRODUCT": "Workstation",
            "PRICE": 1450.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Enterprise Systems Ltd",
            "COUNTRY": "Canada",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1004",
            "PRODUCT": "Laptop Pro",
            "PRICE": 1899.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Business Corp",
            "COUNTRY": "UK",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1005",
            "PRODUCT": "Gaming Laptop",
            "PRICE": 1250.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Digital Ventures",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1006",
            "PRODUCT": "Smart Watch",
            "PRICE": 299.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Gadget Store",
            "COUNTRY": "Australia",
            "SALESGROUP": "Consumer Electronics"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1007",
            "PRODUCT": "Ergonomic Chair",
            "PRICE": 445.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Office Outfitters",
            "COUNTRY": "France",
            "SALESGROUP": "Office Furniture"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1008",
            "PRODUCT": "Storage Array",
            "PRICE": 3500.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "CloudTech Systems",
            "COUNTRY": "Singapore",
            "SALESGROUP": "Data Infrastructure"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1009",
            "PRODUCT": "Network Switch",
            "PRICE": 175.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "ConnectIT",
            "COUNTRY": "Japan",
            "SALESGROUP": "Networking Devices"
        }
    ]
}
 
 

For better readability, here is the data in table format:

 
import pandas as pd

sample_data = pd.DataFrame(payload["rows"])
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

Running the predictions

To run the predictions, we will use the requests library to send an HTTP POST request to the RPT-1 deployment endpoint. The request will include our test data and the authorization token.

 
AICORE_API_URL = os.environ["AICORE_API_URL"].rstrip("/")
AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP = os.environ.get("AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP", "default")
RPT1_DEPLOYMENT_ID = os.environ.get("RPT1L_DEPLOYMENT_ID")

if not RPT1_DEPLOYMENT_ID:
    raise ValueError("Missing RPT1L_DEPLOYMENT_ID in .env (deployment id from AI Launchpad).")

url = f"{AICORE_API_URL}/inference/deployments/{RPT1_DEPLOYMENT_ID}/predict"

headers = {
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}",
    "AI-Resource-Group": AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP,
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Accept": "application/json",
}

response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, json=payload, timeout=120)
response.raise_for_status()
 
 

Analyzing the results

Let's take a look at the results returned by RPT-1. Here are the predictions in the raw JSON format:

 
import json

data = response.json()
preds = data["predictions"]
print(json.dumps(preds, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False))
 
[
  {
    "ID": 1001,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": 0.93,
        "prediction": "Enterprise Solutions"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "ID": 1002,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": 0.78,
        "prediction": "Office Furniture"
      }
    ]
  }
]
 
 

Note that the result looks different from what we saw in the playground, which hosts the RPT-1-OSS model. RPT-1-Large also returns a confidence score for each prediction.

Let's merge these predictions back into the tabular format to see the results more clearly:

 
preds_df = sample_data.copy(deep=True)

preds_df["ID"] = preds_df["ID"].astype(int)

for pred in preds:
    row_idx = int(pred["ID"])
    predicted_value = pred["SALESGROUP"][0]["prediction"]
    preds_df.loc[preds_df["ID"] == row_idx, "SALESGROUP"] = predicted_value

preds_df
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSAEnterprise Solutions
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermanyOffice Furniture
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

For comparison, here is the original sample data before predictions:

 
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

Conclusion

We've successfully transitioned from using SAP-RPT-1 in the playground to deploying and using it via AI Core. This setup allows you to use RPT-1 in a scalable, production-like environment. On the playground, for example, you quickly hit limits if you try more complex scenarios or larger datasets. Using a deployment via AI Core overcomes these limitations.

I already have quite a few ideas for building more complex applications using RPT-1 and AI Core. Which scenarios will you build first? Let me know in the comments!

entry.title: Re: Ant initialize error for SAP Commerce on-prem 2205.44
entry.content:
In 2205.44, Ant expects Rush to already exist, but under some conditions it is not bootstrapped before invocation, leading to:

Invoking "rush update --bypass-policy"
The system cannot find the path specified.

It may have worked on 2211.37 beccause Rush was either already present from previous install, or Ant bootstrapped it correctly before calling it.

In 2205.44 it looks like Ant target calls rush update before ensuring node_modules/.bin/rush.cmd exists. So Ant literally tries to execute a file that isnt there yet. Check if you have the following file after the error . It may not exist:-

hybris\bin\modules\smartedit\smartedittools\common\node_modules\.bin\rush.cmd.


You may try to manually bootstrap smartedit tooling by installing Rush .

entry.title: Re: Welcome SAP-RPT-1! What is it? How can you try it out?
entry.content:
That is a very good question and based on my knowledge it completely depends on the token count given to the transformer as an input and also the parameter count of the transformer that is processing the input. I am not sure about RPT-1 in general, but from what I have learned about LLMs in general, the quality of the result for the single value prediction depends a lot on the total available data that is used to train the data. To address your question of how would the guess be for range of 103-7840, I feel the better the model is trained with enough tokens from the input side for each token in the transformer's end, the better the output prediction is going to be. It was beautifully explained in the Chinchilla's law where it states, for a fixed compute budget, you should not just make models bigger, you should also give them a lot more data. 


Do check it out to know more in detail: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/artificial-intelligence/chinchilla-scaling-laws/

Apologies for any typos.

entry.title: Re: How to check authroization header in iFlow
entry.content:
There are a few things to consider:

  • standard authorization/Authorization header (both contain the same value) is hidden by default for security purposes, but you can pass its value via content modifier to a custom header or property to make it visible
  • Remember to assign Data Type as java.lang.String, otherwise, it may contain unwanted values like org.apache.camel.converter.stream.InputStreamCache or org.apache.camel.converter.stream.ByteArrayInputStreamCache
  • Remember to allowlist Authorization in the iFlow runtime configuration
  • Based on my observations, when sender calls via Basic Auth, this value is present, but when the source system calls via OAuth, the header contains empty value. Let me know if you experience the same behavior. In any case, this is sufficient to identify whether the iFlow is called via Basic Auth or OAuth

BR

Mateusz

entry.title: Re: Error when updating a user's default layout
entry.content:
Please see details below for your reference on why user encounter the error on "This entry already exists in the following tables 'Document Standards' (RDFL) (ODBC -2035) [Message 131-183]".
  • Before you change the default, other form has been set previously as the default for the current user and all BPs which for example is the Layout 1.
  • Changing the default to for example Layout 2 by using the checkbox as well for "Set as Default for all BPs (for Whom a Default Layout Has Not Been Assigned)" will not override the previous default of Layout 1. To be able to successfully change, user will need to perform the following:
  1. Select the existing default.
  2. Click on Set as Default
  3. Tick the Set as Default for Specified BP
  4. Click Clear button.
  5. Click Update
  6. Click OK
  7. Click OK
  8. Click Update.
  • Then you can now proceed to change the default by using the "Set as Default for all BPs (for Whom a Default Layout Has Not Been Assigned)".

entry.title: Re: I cannot TECO the production order because open outbo...
entry.content:
Someone have done the GI (261 movement) from S4 instead of doing it from the EWM. This cause the issue.
It seems they don't have that mapping for the item type in the Outbound Delivery which is why it is getting stuck in EWM. So what we can do is to delete/cancel the delivery in S/4. 

You can check the deliveries in LIPS table, filter using the Process Order number. 

Reset the Distrib Status of the delivery in S/4 - go to SE37, execute /SPE/DELV_RESET_DIST_STATUS. Input the Outbound Delivery number in IT_DELIVERY_KEYS - VBELN. Then execute. 

Go to VL02N and input the outbound delivery number, then delete

entry.title: Re: OOTB Cache regions issue
entry.content:
Hello SukanyaM

Check if the cache is globally disabled at runtime . Even if properties are the same, CCv2 / dev / stage environments often disable cache via JVM flags or env vars.
check in hac->configuration for properties like xxx.cache.enabled and check if those are true

If it is false, all cache regions exist but are never used, resulting in:

Hits = 0

Misses = 0

Invalidations still increase.

Once you set these properties to true, restart the nodes.

entry.title: Modernize Planning: Universal Hierarchy in SAP Revenue Growth Management for SAP Cloud ERP Customers
entry.content:
1. Navigating Hierarchy Complexity

For emerging consumer products companies, managing customer and product hierarchies is a fundamental challenge for commercial planning. This complexity is inherent to the fast-moving industry, where product portfolios evolve with new launches and discontinuations, customer organizations restructure, and planning cycles need to align with diverse retailer calendars. System administrators and Key Account Managers (KAMs) alike face the challenge of ensuring data consistency, planning accuracy, and operational efficiency amidst these changes. Traditional approaches often lead to manual, error-prone adjustments and a constant game of catch-up.

For customers adopting SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the introduction of the Universal Hierarchy Framework in SAP Revenue Growth Management addresses these pain points, offering a time-aware, unified, and streamlined approach to hierarchy management.

 

2. Universal Hierarchy Framework: A Future-Proof Foundation for Revenue Growth

SAP Revenue Growth Management is designed to empower CPG companies with robust tools for account planning, promotion management, and analytics. A critical capability for customers of SAP Cloud ERP is the Universal Hierarchy Framework. We now support both customer and product hierarchies that are time-dependent and versionedcapable of consuming SAP Public Cloud's Universal Hierarchy Framework. This means customers now have a future-proof way to manage hierarchies, transforming them as time-aware assets for promotion planning and execution.

For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management. 

 

3. Key Functionalities of Universal Hierarchy Framework in SAP Revenue Growth Management

3.1. Plan Ahead with Confidence: Time-Dependent Hierarchies

The ability to plan hierarchy changes in advance is a foundational benefit of the Universal Hierarchy Framework provided by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which SAP Revenue Growth Management now supports. Unlike traditional hierarchies where updates take effect immediately, the Universal Hierarchy Framework allows system admins or KAMs to define validity periods for both customer and product hierarchies. This means users can plan and schedule entire hierarchy changessuch as a sales region reorganization or a new product category introductionwell in advance, with changes becoming effective automatically on a specified date.

  • Proactive Workflow Alignment

According to user research, portfolio reviews and hierarchy changes are typically planned months in advance. With the Universal Hierarchy Framework, users can set up all necessary changes far in advance for the next planning yearand avoid end-of-year rushes before the holiday season, directly aligning system updates with strategic business cycles.

  • Reduced Operational Risk

By allowing changes to be scheduled and automatically activated, system admins and KAMs significantly reduce the risk of errors or missed updates during critical periods, ensuring that planning and execution always reflect the intended future organizational reality.

 

3.2. Unified View: Managing MultiVersion Product Hierarchies in a Single Screen

Businesses rarely operate on a single, fixed product hierarchy version for a long period of time. The Universal Hierarchy Framework recognizes this reality by supporting multiple timebound product hierarchy versions. SAP Revenue Growth Management introduces a unified view a onescreen user experience that presents all relevant hierarchy versions on a single screen. This allows KAMs to view and select products or categories across different hierarchy versions without switching contexts, ensuring a complete and continuous planning overview.

One-Screen Transparency

  • Workflow: For example, in a 2026 ready meals account plan, salad belongs to product hierarchy A (PH A) in the first half of the year, and pizza is introduced in the latter half under product hierarchy B (PH B). When a KAM plans a promotion for both items, they need to access them on one screen.
  • A Unified View: By default, the UI primarily displays the earliest valid hierarchy version (e.g. PH A) for the selected planning period. Users are notified that multiple hierarchy versions are available and can switch between versions on the same page. This one-screen view, validated by user research, reduces navigation effort and prevents confusion associated with managing disjointed views.

 

 

Uninterrupted Focus for Informed Business Decisions

  • Workflow: If a KAM views PH B, which excludes "salad", they can still find "salad" in the Product Categories in Other Versions section. When the KAM selects salad and switches to PH A where "salad" exists, the UI keeps the selection valid, allowing planning to continue without interruption.
  • Informed Decision-Making: KAMs can identify changes and understand where products sit in the hierarchy structure during a given planning period, providing valuable context for business decisions.
  • Uninterrupted Planning: Product selection remains valid when switching between versions, reducing toggling and keeping KAMs focused on planning tasks.

 

 

3.3. Streamlined Selection: The Fully Expanded Flat List

When users need speed and efficiencyespecially for customer selectiona flat list that presents all available options at a single, non-nested level, is often more effective than a tree structure. In SAP Revenue Growth Management, customer selection uses a fully expanded flat list to speed search and selection.

  • Quick, Effortless Navigation

KAMs looking for a specific customer no longer need to drill down through multiple tree structures. In promotion planning, choosing correct customers quickly is often more critical than understanding the full customer tree. With the flat list, KAMs can search, filter, select, and continuekeeping focus on core planning objectives. This simplification is backed by user research and aligns with natural user behavior.

  • All Options Expanded at Fingertips

Within SAP Revenue Growth Management, flat lists are presented fully expanded by default, enabling users to see all selectable items at once. This creates a simple, efficient experience and is accompanied by search and filter capabilities for productivity.

 

4. Co-Innovation: Shape Universal Hierarchy Management

The introduction of Universal Hierarchy Framework is a significant step in enabling customers on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to utilize SAP Revenue Growth Management. By providing time-dependent hierarchies, unified multi-version views, and streamlined selection experiences, we aim to help emerging small and medium-sized companies in the consumer product industry to stay agile and competitive in a rapidly changing market.

If you're an existing or a prospective customer of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you're more than welcome to join our co-innovation for Universal Hierarchies. Contact us today at RGM_Engage@sap.com to start the journey toward modernizing your trade promotion management and embracing a more agile approach to planning.

 

Final Note: The support for Universal Hierarchies in SAP Revenue Growth Management is scheduled to become available in January 2026, in support of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Secure your spot as a co-innovation partner today and lets drive your revenue growth.

 

More Information

Documentation on SAP Help Portal

Topic Page for SAP Revenue Growth Management

    • Decoding Promotional Success: Embedded Analytics in SAP Revenue Growth Management

entry.title: The Date Is Technically Correct but HR Is Still Not Happy
entry.content:
The Date Is Technically Correct but HR Is Still Not Happy

A Practical How-To for Resignation and Last Working Date Logic in SAP SuccessFactors EC

It usually starts with a resignation case that looks harmless.

The system shows a date.
Payroll confirms the calculation.
Technically, everything is correct.

And then HR says:

This is not how resignations work in real life.

If youve implemented SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, youve heard this before. Especially during UAT. Especially when exits, notice periods, and payroll deadlines are involved.

This how-to article explains how to fix one of the most common and most underestimated gaps in EC:
Date of Resignation and Last Working Date logic when time, weekends, and notice periods collide.

 

Why This Problem Shows Up in Almost Every EC Project

Out of the box, Employee Central treats dates exactly as dates.

  • A resignation submitted on Sunday is still Sunday
  • A resignation submitted at 6:31 PM is still today
  • A notice period end date can land on a weekend without any warning

From a system point of view, nothing is wrong.
From a business point of view, this causes confusion, rework, and manual overrides.

HR teams think in:

  • Working days
  • Office cut-off times
  • Payroll processing realities

This how-to focuses on aligning system logic with business reality.

 

Business Requirement (What We Are Solving)

Date of Resignation (DOR)

  • If an employee submits resignation after 6:30 PM IST, the system should consider the next working day as the effective Date of Resignation.
  • If an employee submits resignation on Saturday or Sunday, the system should automatically move the Date of Resignation to the first working day.

Last Working Date (LWD) as per Notice Period

  • LWD should be calculated as:
    Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice (calendar days)
  • If the calculated LWD falls on a weekend, it should move to the next working day.

 

System Assumptions (Critical)

Before building the rules, confirm the following:

  • Module: SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
  • System Locale: EN_US
  • Business Time Zone: IST
  • Working Days: Monday to Friday
  • Working Hours Cut-off: 18:30 IST
  • Notice Period Type: Calendar days

Even though the system locale is EN_US, resignation timing must follow IST working hours.
This detail is often missed and causes most after-hours issues.

 

Solution Design (Recommended Approach)

To keep the logic stable and easy to explain during UAT, the solution is split into two independent EC Business Rules:

  1. Date of Resignation Adjustment Rule
  2. Last Working Date as per Notice Period Rule

Each rule has a clear responsibility and does not interfere with the other.

 

Rule 1: Adjust Date of Resignation

(After Hours & Weekend Handling)

Purpose

Ensure the effective Date of Resignation always falls on a working day.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Field: Date of Resignation

Logic Overview

  1. Convert system DateTime to IST using UTC offset (5.5).
  2. If time is on or after 18:30 IST, shift DOR to the next day.
  3. Check day of week:
    • Saturday add 2 days
    • Sunday add 1 day

Outcome

The system stores a business-valid Date of Resignation, not just the submission date.

 

 

Rule 2: Calculate Last Working Date as per Notice Period

Purpose

Calculate LWD correctly and prevent it from falling on a weekend.

Rule Setup

  • Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements
  • Base Object: Employment Details
  • Execution: On Change
  • Trigger Fields:
    • Date of Resignation
    • Required Days of Notice

Step 1: Provisional LWD

Provisional LWD = Date of Resignation + Required Days of Notice

This uses calendar days, as defined by policy.

Step 2: Weekend Validation

  • Saturday add 2 days
  • Sunday add 1 day
  • Weekday no change

Outcome

The final Last Working Date as per Notice Period always lands on a working day.

 

 

 

 

Important Detail: How Notice Period Is Counted

This is where most confusion happens.

In SuccessFactors:

  • When you add calendar days, the Date of Resignation is already included.

Example

  • Effective Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Required Days of Notice: 45

Correct system result:

  • Last Working Date = 28-Jan-2026

Adding one extra day here would be incorrect.

 

End-to-End Test Scenario

Input

  • Date of Resignation entered: 14-Dec-2025 (Sunday)
  • Required Days of Notice: 45
  • Submission time: After 6:30 PM IST

System Result

  1. Effective DOR 15-Dec-2025 (Monday)
  2. Provisional LWD 28-Jan-2026
  3. Weekend check Not required

Final Values

  • Date of Resignation: 15-Dec-2025
  • Last Working Date as per NP: 28-Jan-2026

 

 

Rule Assignment Summary

Rule

Field

Execution

DOR Adjustment Rule

Date of Resignation

On Change

LWD Calculation Rule

Last Working Date as per NP

On Change

This sequencing avoids circular updates and ensures consistent behaviour.

 

Key Takeaways

  • Normalize Date of Resignation first
  • Separate resignation timing logic from notice period logic
  • EN_US locale does not imply US working hours
  • Weekend handling must be explicit in EC
  • Small date errors create big HR trust issues

 

Closing Note

Resignation logic is one of those areas where the system is judged not by its features, but by its judgment.

When dates behave the way HR expects, no one notices.
When they dont, everyone does.

Getting this right is less about complex configuration and more about understanding how business actually works.

entry.title: Re: Managing Vehicles in SAP Asset Management and SAP SSAM
entry.content:
Greetings,

you culd look into SAP fleet management solution:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e98c7c41bbe8439e90daa5c114a7573b/0e7bbb53707db44ce10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US

It includes some additional functionalioties such as automatic fuel consumtion etc.

But overall vehicles are no different than any other equipment. You need to define which EAM processes are relevant for this type of technical object and explore the possibilities in scope of standard EAM functionalities (preventive, corrective, reactive, ...).

You would want to separate these objects by special equipment type, store additional data in a class and classify the individual equipment and you probably also want to have counters to track kilometers and trigger preventive maintenance based on that.

Best regards, M.

Solution: After applying the note(2253571), you may still encounter errors when validating the XML file using the banks validator. These errors are usually related to specific XML tags that do not fully match the banks required format.

To address this, additional customizing in DMEE is required. Adjust or map the XML tags that are causing validation errors according to the banks specifications. Once the DMEE tree is aligned with the bank requirements, the XML file should pass the validation successfully.

entry.title: SAP Learning Practice System Stuck on Please wait, session is preparing How to Fix It
entry.content:
If youre following the SAP Learning  Basic ABAP Programming course or trying to use the SAP BTP ABAP Environment practice system, you might encounter this frustrating issue:

Please wait, session is preparing
Session keeps loading and never starts

I ran into this myself, so heres whats actually happening and how to fix it.

Whats the Problem?

SAP provides a preconfigured practice system for ABAP courses.
This system already contains the data and configuration needed to:

  • Complete exercises from Basic ABAP Programming

  • Experiment with SAP BTP ABAP Environment

However, if your local setup or project connection is incorrect, the session may never finish loading.

Common Reasons Why This Happens

1Eclipse + ADT Tools Are Not Installed Correctly

To work with the ABAP practice system, you must have:

  • Eclipse IDE installed

  • ABAP Development Tools (ADT) plugin added

SAPs official installation guide:
https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-install-adt.html

If ADT is missing or outdated, the session will fail silently.

2Wrong ABAP Service Instance URL (Very Common )

This was the main issue in my case.

When creating an ABAP Cloud Project, Eclipse asks for:

  • ABAP service instance URL

If you accidentally use:

  • An ABAP service URL from your own SAP BTP Trial account

The SAP Learning practice session will get stuck on Please wait, session is loading.

The Correct Solution

Step 1: Use the Provided Practice System URL

When you enrolled in the SAP Learning course, you downloaded a file (usually):

  • s4d_ConfigFile

  • it Includes a README file

Inside that README, youll find the correct ABAP service instance URL
This URL is specifically linked to the SAP Learning practice system

Step 2: Create a NEW ABAP Cloud Project

  • Open Eclipse

  • Create a new ABAP Cloud Project

  • Paste the ABAP service instance URL from the README

  • Do NOT use your own BTP trial URL

Once I did this, the session loaded immediately.

 

At the end, you will see that the cloud project willl be added

entry.title: Re: Does the "Menu" button in the tab strip not fire chan...
entry.content:
Hi,

events are only fired for actions which cause an interaction with the application (server).
"Cancel" will cause a roundtrip to the application - SAP GUI sending the respective vKey to the server and the application reacts accordingly. However, all options from the menu which are not related to the application, but to SAP GUI itself (like calling options dialog) do not cause events and do not have to, because this is pure SAP GUI stuff which cannot be automated via SAP GUI Scripting anyway and which does not need any interaction with the application.

Best regards,
Frank

entry.title: Re: Integrate My Inbox link to SAP Flexible Workflow E-Mail notification
entry.content:
Hello, 

I think from an Clean Extensibility perspective, it is not recommended to extend C_WORKFLOWTASK. It is used in many standard templates and the End User Text label indicates it as: "DEPRECATED: Work item with text info" (as of S4 PCE 2023 FPS03)

Instead I would follow the recommendation in SAP note 3115396 and create an application-specific e-mail template based on my own CDS view. 

In SE80, you can create you own e-mail template, define your CDS view and set in Eclipse + ADT the API state to C1 released. Then your e-mail template will show up in the FIORI app for E-Mail templates as predelivered template and you can take it from there. 

Note to set the API state, only click once in the Eclipse-tree on it (In case you double click, then it opens in the Eclipse integrated GUI and it will not show the API state in Properties). 

Best regards,
Stefan

Customers with a more complex setup will probably also prefer to use a pipeline rather than CAP Console for deployment. Currently we are more focused on initial deployments, demos and experimentation rather than productive deployments.

Will try to communicate this more clearly in the future, so customers do not assume that CAP Console is a best practice for productive deployments.

entry.title: Re: Syntax error snote
entry.content:
My answer is generic to any problem when installing a note with SNOTE:

  1. SNOTE automatically retrieves all the prerequisite SAP notes.
  2. Make sure you applied the manual instructions indicated in the SAP notes.
  3. Make sure you have installed all the SAP notes related to SNOTE (in case there's a bug with SNOTE).
  4. It may happen, but it's rare, that there's a problem with very recent SAP notes. In that case, contact SAP Support.

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA SQL Script : substring the string
entry.content:
You could use SUBSTRING_REGEXPR function. Here is an example

WITH MyDummyData AS (
    SELECT '1/22' AS input_string FROM DUMMY
    UNION ALL
    SELECT '221/22/333/4444' AS input_string FROM DUMMY
)
SELECT 
    input_string,
    SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('[^/]+$' IN input_string) AS extracted_value
FROM MyDummyData

entry.title: Need access to reporting section in SAP for Me to view the utilization of licenses and resources
entry.content:
To access Reporting - SAP for Me, it is necessary for your S-user to have the "Display Support Situation Reporting" authorization. 

Here are the steps to request the appropriate authorization:  

How to request an S-user authorization: 

Contact your Super Administrators to assign you the required authorizations on the correct level. If you don't know the administrators at your company, visit Access and Authorizations (part "Who is my administrator?"). Alternatively use the Self-Service Authorization Request as documented in KBA2891528. After you submit your request, the Super administrator will only need to approve it.

For additional details, you may refer to the documentation in KBA 3336856 - How to access Customer Insights Dashboard - SAP for Me

If you have any further questions or need additional assistance, please let me know.  

Best Regards,  
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Automatic Payment Run Identification in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Jessica,

In the document generated for the payment e.g. 2000000xxx will have the following information in the header text: 20251112-RUN05, where the payment run date is the date 12th of Nov 2025 and run ID is RUN05. This is system generated string in the document generated during payment run. Hope this helps you to identify the string based which you can reconcile the payments. Let us know if helps or you have further query.

Regards.

entry.title: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Motivation

In my previous blog I explained the Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting and when it needs adjustment by customers.

In this blog I will explain how to copy and adjust the underlying analytical queries and adjust the selection to prepare them for a customized review booklet. It is for key users and technical consultants.

Since we did enhancements in the booklet with SAP Cloud ERP 2602, as announced in the previous blog, we had to create new analytical queries, which I will already use in my screenshots. I recommend to wait for 2602 to do the adjustments, so you already have the new features for several company codes and currencies in your customized booklet.

Copying the SAP delivered queries

Launch the App Custom Analytical Queries and Services (F1572A) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST. Click on the link Manage Queries. In the next screen click the button Copy.

Figure 1: Copy the first SAP delivered query 

In the pop-up, name your custom query, e.g. YY1_CUSTCOMPMARG and as the source query specify C_COMPANYMARGINQUERY_2 (for 2602 release, in 2508 it would be C_COMPANYMARGINQUERY).

This query is used on the Company Margin (Full Year) page group of the booklet.

Click OK and on the next screen give your new customer query a name, e.g. Company Margin Custom Query.

Figure 2: Name custom query

 Then click on the Fields tab.

Figure 3: Optionally add a remove fields

Here you can optionally add or remove fields in the query to be used or not in the booklet.

The list of available fields comes from the underlying cube I_CompanyMarginCube_2 (in 2602, or I_CompanyMarginCube in 2508) and can only be changed by SAP.

If you also want the Year-to-Date, Fiscal Quarter or Fiscal Period comparison page groups, which are available in the SAP delivered booklet, in you customized booklet, please repeat the steps above for the SAP delivered query C_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY_2 (in 2602, or C_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY in 2508) after completing the following steps for the first query.

 

Figure 4: Copy the second SAP delivered query 

 

Adjusting the selection criteria in the custom query

Next click on the tab Model. You will see the list of measures (or key figures) used in the booklet.

As explained in the previous blog, you need to adjust the selection of Read Key Figures, if you do not use the SAP best practices Functional Areas.

But lets first see the usage of the semantic tags on the Read Key Figures.

Select e.g. the measure Billed Revenue (technical name BilledRevenueAmntInDispCrry). Then turn on Sematic Tag selection criteria. 

Figure 5: Sematic Tag selection of Read Key Figure

 You will see, that the semantic tag BILL_REV is used to read billed revenues. Please do not change this.

Now you can go through the list of Read Key Figures to decide, where the Functional Area selection needs to be adjusted.

Figure 6: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

 As an example, lets take Cost of Goods Sold Variable (technical name VariableCOGSAmntInDispCrry). Select the measure from the list and activate Functional Area selection criteria. 

Figure 7: Change Functional Area selection for COGS

 You see the SAP best practices Functional Areas YB18 (Cost of Goods Sold) and YB25 (Consulting/Services) are used to read COGS for product or service centric business processes.

You can now change them to the ones you use in your respective sales scenarios.

Figure 8: Add Functional Area selection

 The same applies for the measure Cost of Goods Sold Fixed (technical name FxdCOGSAmtInDspCrcy.

 As another example lets take the measure Administration Overhead (technical name AdminOverheadAmtInDspCrcy).

In the SAP delivered query the Functional Area YB40 is used for Administration. You can now replace with your own.

Figure 9: Replace Functional Area selection

Please complete this task for all measures, which need adjustment of Functional Area.

If you have copied the query for the period comparison pages, please do the same there. It contains the same measure structure.

 

Optional: Change default values for filters and parameters

The query also contains same default values for general selection in the booklet. You can optionally change them, so the apply for all users in your customized booklet.

For example, if you want to use your own Financial Statement Version (please see previous blog), go on the tab Parameters, select the Financial Statement Version and change the default value. 

Figure 10: Change default values of parameters

 Please note, that the FSV can stay a filter in the booklet and can later be changed by an end user again.

 Another example is to change the default value of the global filter Currency Field, which is introduced in 2602.

Go on the tab Filter and select Currency Field. The default value is Company Code Currency (CCC). You can change e.g. to Global Currency (GC).

Figure 11: Change default values of filters 

 

Check and publish your custom queries

In the next step please go to the tab Logs and click the button Check.

No errors should appear in the logs and you can click Publish.

Figure 12: Publish custom query

 Please repeat for second query.

 

Create InA Service with both customer queries

The custom booklet will require an InA Service which contain the custom queries.

To create it, go back to the start page of the App Custom Analytical Queries and Services (F1572A) and click Manage InA Services, then click Create.

Figure 13: Create custom InA Service

 Give it a name, a label and click OK.

Next add your custom queries to it with Add query and publish the service. 

Figure 14: Add custom queries

 

Create custom review booklet

You can now create your own review booklet based on the InA Service.

Please launch the App Manage KPIs and Reports (F2814) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST.

Select the tab Review Booklets and click Create. 

Figure 15: Create review booklet.

Give it an ID, a name and description and click Create. 

Figure 16: Open configuration for custom review booklet

 Now click Open Configuration to access the review booklet designer. On the tab General specify your custom Ina Service. 

Figure 17: Add custom Ina Service in custom review booklet

 Then click Generate Content, select your custom queries and click Generate. 

Figure 18: Generate booklet content for customer queries

This will prepare the data providers for the booklet.

You now can go through the booklet designer and customize your pages groups, pages, row and column sets, etc.

Please see the SAP help how to work with the review booklet designer: Configuring a Review Booklet

This is a manual step, which cant be avoided by coping the SAP delivered review booklet, since all settings in the review booklet designer depend on the used queries.

You can however have a look at the SAP delivered booklet as a reference how to configure yours.

Figure 19: Reference Business Pages in SAP delivered booklet

 

Conclusion

You now know, how to customize a query and create a custom review booklet on top of it.

With this know-how you can also customize other SAP delivered review booklets.

The article can also give you an idea, how to create your complete own custom analytical queries, using developer extensibility. This is more advanced and would allow you to create an own contribution margin structure with more than 3 levels and different key figures for revenues and costs.

You can also create review booklet on top of self-developed custom analytical queries.

entry.title: Re: How can I maintain restrictions on Block/Unblock in S...
entry.content:
Hi,

Block/Unblock feature is basic and mandatory activity, there is no option to restrict it if you have access to the app for data monitor.

After you run a task successfully, you have to block it and also you cannot close a period until you have unblocked task.

Regards.
